title: Unreliable, difficult to negotiate, and frustrating.
review: ‚Ä¢ The platform has been extremely difficult to manage, with subscription, billing, and cancellation options being confusing and hard to locate. This has created unnecessary friction and time cost.‚Ä¢ Email reliability has been a persistent problem. Messages sent via Zoho have frequently landed in recipients‚Äô spam folders, which is not acceptable for a professional service.‚Ä¢ I have also experienced issues with inbound emails, including legitimate client messages being filtered or blocked, while unsolicited or spam communications continue to come through.‚Ä¢ Overall, the system has created more administrative burden and stress than it has saved, despite significant effort to configure it correctly.For a paid business email service, this level of complexity and unreliability has ultimately made it unsuitable for my needs.

title: Despite providing valid‚Ä¶
review: 0 Stars! private and Business.Despite providing valid government-issued identification and formally requesting account deletion under the GDPR, Zoho repeatedly refused to process the request unless I regained access to a compromised email account or modified DNS records. Both requirements are technically and practically impossible in the context of a documented security incident and, more importantly, are not required under EU data protection law.Instead of facilitating my statutory rights, the process was repeatedly delayed, redirected, and blocked by references to internal ‚Äúsecurity‚Äù procedures that appear to override, rather than comply with, GDPR obligations.This raises serious questions about Zoho‚Äôs handling of data subject rights, internal compliance training, and escalation procedures in the EU context.Based on this experience, I cannot recommend Zoho to individuals or organizations that rely on legally compliant, transparent, and user-respecting data protection processes.

title: I spent nearly a week tryiPaid for support, received none ‚Äì avoid if you need helpng to‚Ä¶
review: I spent nearly a week trying to complete a basic Zoho Mail setup (routing info@ and accounts@ to my main inbox). After days of confusion, I upgraded to Zoho Workplace Professional specifically to get support.Despite paying, opening a detailed support ticket, and clearly explaining what I needed, nothing was resolved. Nearly 24 hours later, there was still no practical assistance, no setup completed, and no urgency shown.Zoho‚Äôs system is needlessly complex, especially for single-user businesses. Simple tasks are buried behind:confusing group vs shared mailbox logicinconsistent admin screensdocumentation that does not match the UIEven worse, paid support is slow and ineffective. I explicitly explained that I have dyslexia and mental health difficulties, and that prolonged technical back-and-forth was causing significant stress. This was ignored.The result:I paid for a service upgrade that delivered no supportEmail setup remained brokenI was forced to abandon the platform and look elsewhereZoho looks good on paper, but if you actually need human help, onboarding assistance, or timely support, this is not the platform.

title: As a professional reviewer and someone‚Ä¶
review: As a professional reviewer and someone who has spent years evaluating enterprise tools, productivity suites, CRM ecosystems and operational software, I believe in calling out gaps with clarity so organisations can make informed decisions. After a deep and objective analysis of the Zoho environment, my experience has been consistently challenging across quality, usability and reliability.Zoho attracts customers with a low entry price but once you start using the platform in real business conditions, the limitations and unexpected system behaviour become very visible.First. Calendar and email sync issues are extremely unreliable. Meeting invites created in Zoho Mail can disappear without any trace. Imagine having a million dollar meeting scheduled and it simply vanishes. No logs. No explanation.Second. Simple actions like enabling your camera for an online meeting are buried inside obscure settings. It feels less like a productivity tool and more like a treasure hunt inside a coal mine.Third. The feature that is supposed to automatically download images from trusted senders does not work consistently. You approve the sender yet the system keeps asking every time. This removes the value of the feature entirely.Fourth. Zoho Meeting is connected to Zoho Mail but the calendar does not display the meetings properly. You will find your scheduled meetings only inside Zoho Meeting while the Mail calendar remains empty. A confusing and risky experience for any business user.Fifth. Support responds quickly with tickets but the resolutions rarely solve the actual problems. Most issues continue without any meaningful fix.Sixth. The user experience across the ecosystem is poor. Important items are hidden, navigation is confusing and the overall feeling is that this is not a reliable environment to run a serious business operation.Seventh. Security configuration is unnecessarily complicated. In Google and Microsoft environments, configuration is straightforward. In Zoho, you either need a technical expert or you spend hours reading articles and chatting with support just to set up a standard security layer.There are many more functional inconsistencies that I encountered during my in depth testing. Similar behavioural issues are visible in their CRM and Desk products, so organisations should be very cautious about implementing Zoho at scale. There is a very high probability of experiencing real time glitches during business critical workflows.One of the biggest concerns is the pricing structure. It looks simple from the outside but it is designed in layers that force you into multiple subscriptions. The low initial cost disappears once you add even a basic productivity requirement.For example. Zoho Mail is cheap but it does not include documents such as spreadsheets or word processors. Once you need them, there is an add on. When you add that, you are prompted to subscribe to the drive. When you subscribe to the drive, you are encouraged to subscribe to the workspace. When you combine all these layers, the total cost reaches the same level as Google and in some cases even higher. The illusion of affordability disappears very quickly.My recommendation. Do not decide based only on low pricing. Consider long term vision, product maturity, reliability, user experience, security and organisational satisfaction. These are the factors that determine whether a tool will scale with your business or slow you down.Good luck to anyone evaluating tools for their organisation. Choose wisely and invest in platforms that prioritise performance and customer value over complexity and lock in pricing.

title: Terrible
review: I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm having to write this, but my experience moving my emails over to Zoho has been terrible.Firstly, I ended up with a structure I didn‚Äôt need for my business emails. In an attempt to restructure them properly, I deleted two email accounts (and all emails) from the domain and primary account, after making a backup of the emails. Only to find I couldn‚Äôt reopen them separately.I was told it was possible to recover both emails under the original primary account (on the same domain) within 7 days. I lodged a request for email recovery the next morning (day 2). By Wednesday (day 3) they had enabled me to re-add the email addresses to the primary account again, but no emails had been recovered.I again raised it with support (twice in fact). And was told it was being dealt with. I am now on day 5 (technically day 6), and still no update on the recovery of my emails. In two days, the emails will be irretrievable. And I will have lost 3 years of work emails.The backup is useless, because unbeknownst to me, the backup was created as password protected and since the account was closed I have no access to the password. Yet it never asked if I wanted to password protect the zip file.Compared to Google Workspace which we moved from, Zoho Mail feels clunky and unprofessional.

title: Zoho Social: The best for social media management
review: I have been using Zoho Social for a while now, and I have to say it has completely changed the way I manage my social media. It is extremely easy to use and has all the features I need in one place. Scheduling posts across multiple platforms like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter (X), and LinkedIn has never been easier.I especially love how intuitive the dashboard is. I can see all my upcoming posts, track engagement, and plan my content calendar without feeling overwhelmed. The analytics are detailed and helpful, giving me real insights into what content works best and where I need to improve.Another thing I appreciate is how Zoho Social integrates seamlessly with other Zoho apps I use, making it really convenient to manage my marketing and customer interactions from one platform. Overall, it saves me so much time, keeps me organized, and allows me to focus on creating quality content instead of worrying about logistics. I would highly recommend it to anyone serious about managing their social media efficiently.

title: Misleading advertising and unresponsive support ‚Äî preparing to open a chargeback
review: I signed up for Zoho Mail based on the features advertised on their pricing page, specifically CalDAV/CardDAV and ActiveSync support. These are essential for anyone needing proper email + calendar sync on desktop clients (macOS and Windows).After paying for a year up front, I discovered that although these features are listed as included, they do not work on desktop clients on the Mail Lite plan (something not disclosed anywhere on the pricing page).Zoho Support eventually confirmed in writing that desktop ActiveSync is not supported, and that only mobile devices are compatible. The CalDAV/CardDAV screen in the admin panel also lacks the configuration details required for desktop clients, making desktop calendar/contact sync impossible. This is a material omission and renders the plan unusable for its advertised purpose.I requested a refund immediately. Support instructed me to cancel the plan and contact the cancellation team, which I did. I have since received no response at all, despite multiple follow-ups.At this point, I am preparing to initiate a chargeback with my bank due to the service being sold with misleading feature information and the lack of any substantive response from Zoho‚Äôs cancellation department.I strongly advise potential customers to verify in writing that the features you need actually work on the plan you are considering. My experience has been extremely poor, and the lack of transparency around core functionality is unacceptable.

title: A very promising option!
review: Our organization recently trialed the Zoho Social service as we're looking to simplify management of our social media channels, allowing easy scheduling and improving our team's workflow.Our initial impressions have been very positive overall. The analytics are very detailed and useful and there a a ton of great features. It's prices a little higher than other competing products we've looked at but it also seems to be the most complete and fully featured too.The good:1. Scheduling works great and posts always went live at the correct scheduled time.2. Being able to see exactly how many characters remain when writing a post for Twitter and Bluesky is a great help!3. The dashboard gives a great overview of the brand and the in-depth analytics are very thorough and useful to analyzer how all our social accounts are performing.4. Being able to easily view and handle various follower interactions is another highly useful feature. It's very convenient to get engagement notifications from all social accounts all in one place, as well as being able to also respond to any replies or messages as needed.5. The ability to collaborate with our entire team and setup approval workflows is another great feature. It can cost quite a lot extra to add this compared to competing services, also depending on the number of team members, but for smaller teams it's great.What could be improved:1. Whilst at first it appears that Telegram is supported to some extent, this is only for bot interactions. Zoho Social does not support posting messages in Telegram groups or channels. Support for scheduling posts in Telegram channels would have been a great feature to add, although also very few alternatives actually appear to actually support this (we could only find a single one that even claims to have support for this).2. Whilst the interface for making new posts is nice and easy to use, the option to create threads (for Twitter and Bluesky) seems like a bit of an afterthought. It's not as polished as the rest of the interface and the post preview doesn't show any additional posts in the thread, only the first one. Finally, scheduling threads will treat each service (Twitter, Bluesky) as a separate independent post instead of linking the services into a single post; this is a minor issue but effectively means that deleting or rescheduling a thread means you have to change it individually for each service instead of just once like you would normally do with a single-post message.3. Permission roles, whilst adequate, do have a few quirks. It's not possible to customize the default roles to e.g. disallow access to the analytics or Inbox views and it's not possible to give any special permissions to custom roles (e.g. admin permissions, ability to add/remove users). This means that you're forced to use the default admin roles to give users this ability, but you then cannot limit which admin permissions they get or what they can access.4. Certain settings can only be set on the user level and don't apply to all users within a brand, mainly the automatic URL shortening feature. Our organization already generate our own custom short URLs that we use and we currently would have to instruct each team member to disable the automatic URL shortening on their account as it's not possible to disable this globally for all users.

title: Theft, Unreliable Systems, Poor Support, Unauthorised Charges and No Refund
review: I have never had such a disappointing experience with a service provider as I have had with Zoho. What began as a promising platform quickly turned into one of the most frustrating and time-consuming IT experiences I‚Äôve ever dealt with.From the very beginning, there were persistent syncing issues across my email accounts. Emails would regularly take anywhere from 20 to 30 minutes to appear in my inbox, and sometimes they wouldn‚Äôt come through at all until I manually refreshed or signed out and back in again. This wasn‚Äôt an isolated problem ‚Äî it was a daily occurrence, and it severely affected communication with clients and colleagues. For a business platform that markets itself as reliable and professional, these delays were unacceptable.I contacted support multiple times over several months to try and get this resolved. Unfortunately, every interaction left me more frustrated. The support process is painfully slow and disjointed ‚Äî you wait days for an initial response, only to be passed between different agents who don‚Äôt seem to read the previous correspondence or understand the issue. When someone finally offers to connect remotely to your computer, the experience is far from reassuring. It often feels like the technicians are guessing at solutions, trying different settings and configurations at random, rather than providing a clear, structured fix. You‚Äôre essentially watching them stab in the dark, hoping something might work.On several occasions, these interventions actually made things worse ‚Äî for example, triggering password resets or account access problems that forced me to change my password multiple times for no clear reason. There is very little confidence in their technical understanding, and the overall experience feels like trial and error rather than professional IT support.After months of ongoing issues and wasted time, I finally made the decision to move all of my services to Microsoft, which immediately resolved the problems I had been facing with Zoho. Unfortunately, things went from bad to worse when it came to billing and account management.Despite my clear request to close the account and stop all services, Zoho went ahead and took funds from my account without authorization. When I contacted them about this, rather than acknowledging the mistake, they shifted the blame onto me, claiming I hadn‚Äôt cancelled ‚Äúproperly‚Äù through my account portal ‚Äî even though I had explicitly instructed them to cancel in writing. Their response was dismissive and unhelpful: they refused to issue a refund and instead offered to extend a service I no longer required for an additional 12 months.In my view, that is completely unacceptable business practice. Taking money without permission and then refusing to refund it, especially when the service was not used and had been requested to be cancelled, is indefensible.The combination of unreliable systems, poor technical knowledge, slow response times, and a refusal to take accountability for errors paints a very clear picture of a company that is not customer-focused and lacks professionalism.I would strongly caution any business considering Zoho to think very carefully before committing. My experience has been one of constant technical issues, wasted hours on support, and an eventual financial dispute that was handled with little regard for fairness or customer service.Switching away from Zoho to a more stable platform was the best decision I made, but the time and money lost dealing with them is something I won‚Äôt get back. Based on my experience, I would not recommend Zoho to any business that values reliability, transparency, or proper customer care.The update: they emailed 12/11/2025 (Pratap) to say they will look into my review and get back to me within 48 hours. 6 days later no further communication has been received. This really sums up my dealings with them - Be warned stay away and save yourself the hassle.

title: ‚ÄúThe Best All-In-One Social Media Tool for Business Owners‚Äù
review: As a mortgage broker managing multiple digital touchpoints, I trialled several social media management platforms before committing to Zoho Social. After extensive comparison, Zoho Social clearly stands out as the most intuitive, operationally efficient, and insight-rich solution in the market.The platform delivers an exceptional user experience ‚Äî from scheduling content across channels to monitoring engagement and analysing performance. The interface is clean, the workflows are seamless, and the analytics dashboard provides the right level of granularity for data-driven decision-making. For someone in a high-paced industry like mortgage broking, this level of clarity and control is invaluable.What impressed me the most is the platform‚Äôs ability to simplify everything. No clutter. No complexity. Just a robust, well-designed tool that empowers you to execute, measure, and optimise your social media strategy with confidence.If you are a business owner seeking a hassle-free, scalable, and genuinely effective social media management platform, look no further than Zoho Social. It has elevated the way I manage my brand presence ‚Äî and I highly recommend it for any organisation aiming to stay ahead of the curve.

title: Doing down people's business
review: I wish to use Zoho but unfortunately the company is saying to people that they can only run a business if they already have clients on their books and even then those clients cannot be contacted without wining and dining them first and gaining their personal contact-details:Phwhy, oh phwhy is this? Let's test my French:UN: Because they don't want complaints over spamming...yes, and yet to get business you need to make business.Kind of obvious. Think I just thought up a perfect equation.And DUH:Because no-one spam-filters your email-address just because  it has 'help' or 'info' or 'media' or whatever at the beginning of your email-address - they class some prefixes as 'Groups' and further disallow them. Mmm. Welcome to Planet Zoho.No. Spam email-address are judged as such going by the ends of emails, not prefixes, or at least it's this way in 2025. Even then, businesses and organisations are always forming their email-addresses with inapplicable endings, e.g. .org should technically be for 'org...anisations'...while I can tell you that many companies and organisations use other domain-extensions than what they technically should.So, they're doing themselves out of business by turning away companies in requirement of clients and a large portion of clients which have been obtained by companies.Utterly ridiculous and somewhat stupid. And I can't stand stupidity. It does my head in.They can either make life easier for people to get on, or more difficult, and they choose the latter.

It takes the stress out of staying active online and helps me focus on creating great content instead of juggling platforms. For anyone running their own business or managing social accounts solo, I can‚Äôt recommend it enough‚Äîit‚Äôs like having a personal social media assistant that never misses a beat!

review: Let me explain this: there is NO free version of the website. title: Zoho is a breeding ground for spam, scams, and illegal AI-generated marketing
review: I‚Äôve been bombarded with unsolicited spam and AI-generated scam marketing emails coming from Zoho‚Äôs platform and despite multiple reports and unsubscribe attempts, they continue to arrive.Zoho clearly allows and turns a blind eye to illegal mass mailing campaigns run through their system. Many of these messages violate EU and GDPR laws, with no functioning opt-out, no sender transparency, and fake company identities. It‚Äôs a digital free-for-all of fraudsters using Zoho‚Äôs services as a launchpad.What makes it worse is Zoho‚Äôs complete refusal to take accountability. I‚Äôve reported the issue directly to their support, abuse and privacy teams multiple times, provided full headers, and cited clear violations of anti-spam regulations. The response? Not their problem.It‚Äôs one thing for a company to have a few bad actors on their platform. It‚Äôs another to harbor them, profit from their traffic, and ignore victims who are simply asking not to be targeted.If you value your privacy, data integrity, and inbox sanity ‚Äî avoid Zoho like the plague. Their brand has become synonymous with unethical marketing, fake automation, and AI-driven spam at scale.Verdict: A company that should know better ‚Äî but clearly doesn‚Äôt care.

title: Had issues receiving mail
review: I called the office to get help with my business email, as it wasn‚Äôt fully configured and I was trying to get my business going again after a break. I struggled with the setup video, and since my domain is with GoDaddy, they said the rest was up to Zoho. I spoke with Jas, who kindly shared my screen and got everything sorted within minutes. Even though my laptop was slow, he was patient and also helped with a couple of other issues. In a time when good customer service is rare, Jas really delivered. Zoho's affordable pricing is great for solopreneurs like me. Thank you for making my birthday extra smooth‚ÄîI'm genuinely happy!

title: bad customer service 10 cannot solve‚Ä¶
review: I‚Äôm really disappointed with the way this case has been handled. You‚Äôve written the same response several times ‚Äî ‚Äúwe‚Äôll check with the backend team, please wait‚Äù ‚Äî but nothing ever changes. It‚Äôs been weeks, and there is still no real update.Now you‚Äôre telling me to contact them myself. Are you serious? What‚Äôs the point of this support window then ‚Äî to make customers do your job for you?You also never sent me any email confirming that the case was taken in progress or forwarded to the responsible team. Please send that confirmation to my email immediately.Honestly, this whole process feels unprofessional and very frustrating. I‚Äôve been writing to you again and again, and you just keep repeating the same message without any real action.

title: Misleading visitor plan, unresolved issues, and slow support ‚Äì disappointing experience
review: We used Zoho PageSense and faced a critical issue: despite purchasing an annual "10,000 visitors/month" plan, our tracking stopped after reaching 120,000 visitors in total, well before our yearly subscription ended. The system counts yearly, not monthly as advertised‚Äîso when you hit the yearly cap, your experiments are blocked, and you lose tracking for the remainder of your paid term.Customer support was not helpful or responsive. We experienced:No warning when running out of visitors;Repeatedly ignored tickets and emails;Misleading advertising on the plan features;Recommendation: Be very careful with PageSense visitor limits. The yearly plan is NOT what is advertised as "10K/month," and support is slow to reply or resolve major issues. Our experience was frustrating and we cannot recommend the service.

title: THEY ARE THIEVES & CHARGE YOUR CARD INDEFINITELY AFTER CANCELLING
review: THEY ARE THIEVES!!  THEY CHARGED MY CARD TWO YEARS AFTER CANCELLING.  WHEN YOU CANCEL, THEY WILL STILL CHARGE YOUR CARD, THEN HIDE BEHIND THEIR NO REFUNDS POLICY. title: Completely stupid logic.
review: Completely stupid logic.We were using Zoho Invoice for a while without ANY trouble. BUT since we reached the limit, that‚Äôs when the issues started.They force you to move to their super product called Zoho Billing.Okay, that could be fine if you actually need to manage billing cycles and all that blablabla.But I just want to use Zoho Invoice to manage my invoices.And that‚Äôs where the joke begins.We just wanted to use Zoho Invoice as a normal paid product and sleep peacefully. But you can‚Äôt. Why? I don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt know which genius came up with that idea, but wow, brilliant.But that‚Äôs not all. You might say, ‚ÄúOkay, fine, just move to Zoho Billing.‚Äù But you can‚Äôt just switch your base API because the entire API is completely different from Zoho Invoice.So you are stuck in the matrix. You can‚Äôt pay for the product that worked perfectly, and now you have to rebuild your entire billing workflow to fit the new API.Brilliant. Absolutely brilliant.

title: Frustrating, Unreliable, and Poor Support
review: Our entire company is built on Zoho, and changing systems at this point would be a major undertaking, but unfortunately, we‚Äôre seriously questioning whether it‚Äôs worth it. At least once a week, Zoho becomes so slow that it‚Äôs practically unusable. All other software packages we use work fine, so it‚Äôs definitely a Zoho problem. This isn't just an inconvenience, we run a customer-facing shop, and when Zoho is down or so slow it does not load anything, we can‚Äôt serve our clients. We‚Äôve had to turn away customers simply because we couldn‚Äôt access the tools we rely on. That has already cost us multiple clients and damaged our reputation. What makes it worse is the complete lack of support. We‚Äôve reached out for help multiple times, but we get no response. No acknowledgment, no follow-up, nothing. Just automated email how you rate the support White no support is given. Zoho was great and they did have a good support, but those times have been long gone. If you're considering Zoho for your business in 2025, think very carefully about the risk you're taking. It‚Äôs simply unusably slow 1 or 2 days per week, nothing is being done to solve it yet, and there is 0 support from Zoho, except for automated messages that don‚Äôt help with anything.

title: Zoho Social is cool and easy
review: Zoho Social is a powerful social media management platform designed for businesses and agencies to manage their online presence effectively. It offers seamless scheduling, publishing, and monitoring across major platforms like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn, and more. The dashboard is clean and user-friendly, making it easy to track engagement, reach, and performance. Its real-time monitoring and detailed analytics help businesses understand audience behavior and optimize content strategies. Team collaboration features simplify workflow, and integration with other Zoho apps enhances productivity. Overall, Zoho Social is a cost-effective, reliable, and scalable solution for anyone serious about social media marketing.

title: The overall user experience is amazing‚Ä¶
review: The overall user experience is amazing and it gives a overview of every metric that I need to create reports, it also give me valuable insights like good time to post that helps me in my strategy.

title: Very frustrating system!
review: Very frustrating system!! I keep getting kicked out of my account everytime I want to change or update some settings. The dashboard bar doesn't work. You can click on it 100x and nothing happens! You have to clear the cache EVERY SINGLE TIME YOU LOG IN. Which is EVERY SINGLE TIME YOU DO ANYTHING ON THE SYSTEM!! Very frustrating system. User unfriendly. Interface is very confusing. Cheap and affordable but comes with too many headaches. I hate this system. And im stuck with it for a year because they don't offer monthly payments so you cant try it out to see if you like it before you use it. Also its horrid on the cellphone so if you are on the go and need to do something on your phone you will pull out all your hair before getting anything done!

title: It all sA Cautionary Tale: My Struggle to Cancel Zoho Bookstarted with a simple decision
review: It all started with a simple decision: I wanted to cancel my Zoho Books subscription. The software wasn‚Äôt meeting my small business‚Äôs needs, and I figured it would be a straightforward process. I‚Äôd heard of companies making cancellations tricky, but I never imagined the ordeal I was about to face.I reached out to Zoho‚Äôs customer support through their chat system, expecting a quick resolution. The representative was polite but unhelpful, directing me to a set of instructions on their website to cancel my subscription. They sent me a link to a help page titled ‚ÄúHow to Cancel Your Zoho Books Subscription.‚Äù Hopeful, I clicked through, only to find a maze of FAQs and settings menus with no clear ‚ÄúCancel Subscription‚Äù button. The steps described a link that simply didn‚Äôt exist. I double-checked, refreshed, and even tried different browsers, but it was nowhere to be found.Frustrated, I contacted support again. This time, I was told they couldn‚Äôt cancel it from their end and that I had to follow the website‚Äôs process. I explained the missing link, but they insisted it was there and suggested I clear my cache or try another device. I did both‚Äîstill nothing. Hours turned into days as I emailed back and forth, each response from Zoho pointing me to the same nonexistent link. It felt like a deliberate runaround, as if they were banking on me giving up.Meanwhile, my credit card was charged again for another month. I realized I couldn‚Äôt trust Zoho to handle this fairly. Desperate, I called my bank and explained the situation. They flagged the charges as unauthorized and advised me to cancel my credit card to prevent further charges. It was a hassle‚Äîchanging my card meant updating all my other subscriptions and payments‚Äîbut it was the only way to stop Zoho from taking my money.In the end, I got a new card, and the charges stopped. But the experience left me angry and betrayed. Zoho‚Äôs refusal to assist and their broken cancellation process cost me time, stress, and money. I‚Äôm sharing this story to warn others: be cautious with Zoho Books. Never give them your credit card details unless you‚Äôre prepared to fight to get them back. If you‚Äôre considering their service, think twice‚Äîthere are other accounting tools out there that don‚Äôt trap you in a cycle of frustration.
